Award.AwardTitle: Pathways: Emotion and Thinking in Designed Informal Science Environments

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Pathways project focuses on research that explores diverse family visitors' engagement with and thinking about science as they experience exhibits at the Museum of Science, Boston. The research team will work closely with museum staff on the implementation of three studies during which they will systematically investigate the arc of visitors' engagement (cognitive, emotional, and physical) as the visitors experience a range of exhibits. The team will also describe how visitors' engagement relates to their thinking about science concepts. The project team uses a mix of data collection and analysis methods, including self-report measures and physiological data along with the tracking of visitor behavior to understand and articulate engagement, along with information on learners' thinking about scientific concepts and demographic information.

This project will advance the ISE field by offering findings about engagement that account for the applied and complex nature of the museum setting. The research team will be able to help the ISE field move forward in terms of building theoretical understanding about engagement and offering potential lines of inquiry for future research. The results can also be used to inform exhibit and programmatic design as well as how family learning in museums is evaluated.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A primary element in the mission of informal STEM learning institutions is to engage the public--children, adults, families, school groups, and so on--in the scientific experience. Through such engagement meaningful change can take place in improving scientific uderstandings and broadening pusuit of scientific endeavors or careers. And yet, despite this emphasis on engagement and its crucial role in the informal learning setting, the field has been continually hampered by an underdeveloped understanding of the meaning of the term in such contexts and impoverished approaches to measurement. This project represents a significant step foward to remedy such limitations.

Taking an interdisciplinary approach, CAST and its partner the Museum of Science-Boston leveraged measurement techniques from behavioral neuroscience, educational psychology, and informal learning (e.g., measurement including eye-tracking, electrodermal activity, and experience sampling) to develop a multi-dimensional model of engagement. This model can be replicated by others in the field and actively reflects the varied emotional, cognitive, and behavioral aspects of children's engagement experieces in situ during informal and active learning.

The approach was developed through empirical, quantitative methods. Substantially, our results reveal a complex and interesting picture of how core emotion, behavior, and cognition work together to form children's engagement experience and profile. In brief, we find that children exhibit both positive and negative engagement experiences simoultaneously, and, with arousal, these core emotion indicators seem to organize behaviors that should inform design decisions. Struggle through negative emotions like confusion and frustration seem to play a critical role in children's overall engagement profile, especially when sympathetic nervous system activity is high. Parents play a prominent role in their children's experiences, but this role is complex in terms of engagement, generally positive, but perhaps also dampening and contributing to cognitive disengagement. In using this rich approach to the observation of engagement, we were quickly able to identify aspects of children's experiences that were counter-intuitive to the field's current understandings, with implications for how one might support children and parents through the design of informal learning settings. Future work will enable design-based research efforts to experimentally determine what aspects of components contribute most meaningfully to affective experiences, and for whom.

Beyond the implications of our specific results, the outcomes of this project have the potential for far reaching impacts on the field. We mean to provide, through systematic research that spans disciplinary boundaries, a way of thinking about and empirically studying the diversity of engagement experiences in all of its dynamic richness. In addition, the methods employed to measure engagement have not previously been leveraged in coordinated ways, or in authentic, field-oriented learning situations. Generating practically meaningful variables to reflect cognitive, emotional, physical, and social engagement--including indices of positive and negative emotional engagement that are normally distributed and related to other aspects of engagement--provides a major advance in the service of educational research and design-based research.
